trans-unit.source: Within the European Union, the Sixth Environment Action Programme (6th EAP) aims to achieve levels of air quality that do not result in unacceptable impacts on, and risks to, human health and the environment. The EU acts at many levels to reduce exposure to air pollution: through legislation, through co-operation with sectors responsible for air pollution, through national, regional authorities and non-government organisations and through research. EU policies aim to reduce exposure to air pollution by reducing emissions and setting limits and target values for air quality.
trans-unit.target: Fi ħdan l-Unjoni Ewropea, is-Sitt Programm ta' Azzjoni dwar l-Ambjent (s-6 EAP) għandu l-għan li jikseb livelli ta' kwalità ta' arja li ma jirriżultawx f'impatti inaċċettabbli, u f'riskji għas-saħħa tal-bniedem u l-ambjent. L-UE taġixxi f'ħafna livelli sabiex tnaqqas l-espożizzjoni għat-tniġġiż tal-arja: permezz ta' leġiżlazzjoni, permezz tal-kooperazzjoni mas-setturi responsabbli għat-tniġġiż tal-arja, permezz tal-awtoritajiet nazzjonali, reġjonali u organizzazzjonijiet non-governattivi u permezz tar-riċerka. Il-politiki tal-UE għandhom l-għan li jnaqqsu l-espożizzjoni għat-tniġġiż tal-arja billi jitnaqqsu l-emissjonijiet u jistabbilixxu limiti u valuri bħala l-mira għall-kwalità tal-arja.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/air/policy-context

source.p: The Clean Air for Europe (CAFE) programme, established under the 6th EAP, provides long-term, strategic and integrated policy advice concerning air pollution. The 2005 Thematic Strategy on Air Pollution, underpinned by the CAFE programme, sets out ambitious but cost-effective objectives and measures for European air quality policy to 2020.

At a Member State level, the National Emission Ceilings Directive (NEC Directive) imposes emission ceilings (or limits) for emissions of four key air pollutants (nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide, non-methane volatile organic compounds and ammonia) that harm human health and the environment. The European Commission will propose a revised NEC Directive in late 2008. More details are provided here.
Other key EU legislation is targeted at reducing emissions of air pollutants from specific sources, for example:

ul.li: transport;
stationary sources / industrial facilities; and
paints and vehicle refinishing.

source.p: Internationally, the issue of air pollution emissions is also being addressed by the UNECE Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution (the LRTAP Convention) and its protocols. The Gothenburg ‘multi-pollutant’ protocol under the LRTAP Convention contains national emission ceilings that are equal to or less ambitious than those in the EU NEC Directive.

The EU’s new air quality directive, the Directive on Ambient Air Quality and Cleaner Air for Europe, is one of the key measures in place to address air pollution under the Thematic Strategy on Air Pollution. It is the first EU directive to include limits on ambient concentrations of PM2.5 (fine particulate matter). It also consolidates various existing pieces of air quality legislation into a single directive. Governments have been given two years (from 11 June 2008) to bring their legislation in line with the provisions of the Directive.
Until then, the existing EU air quality policy framework remains in place. This legislation has established health-based standards and objectives for a number of air pollutants and includes:

ul.li: The Air Quality Framework Directive. This describes the basic principles concerning the assessment and management of air quality in the Member States. The Directive also lists the pollutants for which air quality standards and objectives have been developed and specified in subsequent legislation (the four ‘Daughter’ Directives);

The ‘Exchange of Information’ Decision, which establishes a reciprocal exchange of information and data from networks and individual stations measuring ambient air pollution within the EU Member States.

source.p: More information on air pollution policies and legislation: European Commission's Environment Directorate-General

target.p: Il- programm Arja Nadifa għall-Ewropa (CAFE), stabbilit taħt is-6 EAP, jipprovdi parir fuq terminu twil, strateġiku u integrat dwar politika dwar it-tniġġis tal-arja. L- Istrateġija Tematika tal-2005 dwar it-Tniġġiż tal-Arja, ibbażata fuq il-programm CAFE, tistabbilixxi objettivi u miżuri ambizzjużi iżda produttivi għall-politika dwar il-kwalità tal-arja Ewropea sal-2020.
target.h2: Emissjonijiet ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja
target.p: Fil-livell ta' Stat Membru, id- Direttiva dwar il-Livelli Nazzjonali Massimi tal-Emissjonijiet (id-Direttiva NEC) timponi livelli massimi tal-emissjonijiet (jew limiti) għall-emissjonijiet ta' erba' pollutanti tal-arja ewlenin (ossidi tan-nitroġenu, diossidu tal-kubrit, komposti organiċi volatili mhux tal-metanu u ammonja) li jagħmlu l-ħsara lis-saħħa tal-bniedem u lill-ambjent. Il-Kummissjoni Ewropea se tipproponi Direttiva NEC riveduta lejn l-aħħar tal-2007. Aktar dettalji huma provduti hawn.
Leġiżlazzjoni oħra ewlenija tal-UE hija mmirata lejn it-tnaqqis tal-emissjonijiet ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja minn sorsi speċifiċi, per eżempju:

ul.li: it-trasport;
sorsi fissi / faċilitajiet industrijali; u
ż-żebgħa u r-rifinitura tal-vetturi.

target.p: Internazzjonalment, il-kwistjoni tat-tniġġis tal-arja qed tkun indirizzata wkoll mill- Konvenzjoni UNECE dwar it-Tniġġis tal-Arja li jivjaġġa ghal distanzi twal u jaqsam minn pajjiż ghal iehor (il-Konvenzjoni LRTAP) u l- protokolli tagħha. Il- protokolll ta' Gotenburg dwar il-'multi-pollutanti' taħt il-Konvenzjoni LRTAP fiha livelli massimi tal-emissjoni li huma ugwali jew anqas ambizzjużi minn dawk fid-Direttiva NEC tal-UE.

Id-direttiva l-ġdida tal-UE dwar il-kwalità tal-arja, id- Direttiva dwar il-Kwalità tal-Arja fil-madwar u Arja aktar nadifa għall-Ewropa, hija waħda mill-miżuri ewlenin li jaħdmu biex jindirizzaw it-tniġġiż tal-arja taħt l-Istrateġija Tematika dwar it-Tniġġis tal-Arja. Din hija l-ewwel direttiva tal-UE li nkludiet il-limiti fuq il-konċentrazzjonijiet tal-madwar tal-PM2.5 (materja tal-partiċelli fina). Hija tikkonsolida wkoll diversi atti leġiżlattivi dwar il-kwalità tal-arja f'direttiva waħda. Il-Gvernijiet ingħataw sentejn (mill-11 ta' Ġunju 2008) biex iġibu l-leġiżlazzjoni tagħhom konformi mad-dispożizzjonijiet tad-Direttiva.

Sa dakinhar, il- politika ta' qafas eżistenti tal-UE dwar il-kwalità tal-arja tibqa' fis-seħħ. Din il-leġiżlazzjoni stabbiliet standards u objettivi ibbażati fuq is-saħħa għal numru ta' pollutanti u tinkludi:

ul.li: Id-Direttiva Qafas dwar il-Kwalità tal-Arja. Din tiddeskrivi l-prinċipji bażiċi li jikkonċernaw il-valutazzjonijiet u l-immaniġġjar tal-kwalità tal-arja fl-Istati Membri. Id-Direttiva telenka wkoll is-sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja li għalihom ġew żviluppati standards u objettivi ta' kwalità tal-arja u speċifikati fil-leġiżlazzjoni sussegwenti (l-erba' Direttivi 'Sekondarji');

Id-Deċiżjoni dwar l-'Iskambju ta' Informazzjoni', li tistabbilixxi skambju reċiproku ta' informazzjoni u dejta min-netwerks u l-istazzjonijiet individwali li jkejlu t-tniġġis tal-arja tal-madwar fi ħdan l-Istati Membri tal-UE.

target.p: Aktar informazzjoni dwar il-linji politiċi u l-leġiżlazzjoni dwar it-tniġġiż tal-arja: Id-Direttorat Ġenerali għall-Ambjent tal-Kummissjoni Ewropea

trans-unit.source: Understanding household consumption patterns is about understanding human behaviour. Consumption patterns in Europe are very different to those 50 years ago. Important factors that drive our consumption include growing incomes, globalisation of the economy, technological breakthroughs (such as the Internet and mobile phones), decreasing household sizes and an ageing population. At the same time, the growing number of goods and services we consume often offsets the efficiency gains we achieved through for example, improved production technologies and processes. As a result, environmental pressures are increasing. Housing, food and drink, and mobility have the greatest environmental impact over their lifecycle in terms of emissions of greenhouse gases, acidifying and ozone-depleting substances as well as resource use.
trans-unit.target: Il-Fehim tal-mudelli ta' konsum tad-djar huwa li wieħed jifhem l-imġieba umana. Il-mudelli ta' konsum fl-Ewropa huma differenti ħafna minn dawk ta' 50 sena ilu. Fatturi important li jkabbru l-konsum tagħna jinkludu żidiet fid-dħul, il-globalizzazzjoni tal-ekonomija, skoperti teknoloġiċi (bħall-internet u t-telefon ċellulari), it-tnaqqis fid-daqs tal-familji u popolazzjoni li qed tixjieħ. Fl-istess ħin, in-numru dejjem jikber ta' oġġetti u servizzi li nikkunsmaw ħafna drabi jikkanċellaw il-kisbiet fl-effiċjenza li ksibna b'per eżempju, teknoloġiji u proċessi ta' produzzjoni aħjar. B'riżultat, il-pressjonijiet ambjentali qed jiżdiedu. Id-djar, l-ikel u x-xorb, u l-mobilità għandhom l-akbar impatt ambjentali fuq iċ-ċiklu tal-ħajja tagħhom f'termini tal-emissjonijiet tal-gassijiet b'effett ta' serra, ta' sustanzi aċidifikanti u li jħassru l-ożonu kif ukoll tal-użu ta' riżorsi.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/households/about-household-consumption

source.p: In Western and Central Europe (EU-27 plus Norway, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland), between 1990 and 2005, consumption expenditure increased by 25 %. Households spend between three and five times more than the public sector. The negative environmental effects of our consumption do not occur only across Europe, but also in other regions of the world. This is mainly a result of resource extraction, production, processing and transportation of the goods we consume in Europe. Tourism is yet another way of exporting our environmental impacts.

Our eating and drinking habits lead to significant environmental pressures. We cause these directly by travelling to the shops, storing, cooking and generating waste. Indirectly, and even more importantly, there exist also the effects linked to food production, processing and transportation.

We buy increasing numbers of electronic goods like TVs, DVDs, PCs, laptops, mobile phones, stereos and kitchen appliances, and we also replace these more frequently. Households account for 28.8 % of electricity used in Europe, and consumption of electricity by the households is on the rise. We also build larger homes for fewer people whilst using more energy in our homes. Space-heating is still by far the largest household energy end-use in the EU (70 %).  Every European citizen on average throws away 520 kg of household waste per year, and this figure is projected to grow further.

Car travel and aviation continue to grow, leading to increasing energy consumption and emission of greenhouse gases. Increased car traffic is a major cause of air pollution and also causes noise problems in cities. Today's trend towards living in new, low-density urban areas is resulting in urban sprawl causing increased consumption of energy, resources, transport and land.

Tourism is one of the fastest growing sectors. Travel to and from the destination is most often done by car or plane. In tourist destinations, the consumption of water and energy, the use of land and the generation of waste and wastewater are all increasing.

target.p: Fil-Punent u fiċ-Ċentru tal-Ewropa (UE-27 flimkien man-Norveġja, Liechtenstein, u l-Iżvizzera), bejn l-1990 u l-2005, in-nefqa fuq il-konsum żdiedet b' 25 %. Id-djar jonfqu bejn tlieta u ħames darbiet aktar mis-settur pubbliku. L-effetti ambjentali negattivi tal-konsum tagħna ma jseħħux biss madwar l-Ewropa, iżda f'reġjuni oħra tad-dinja wkoll. Dan hu l-aktar minħabba l-estrazzjoni tar-riżorsi, il-produzzjoni, l-ipproċessar u t-trasport tal-merkanzija li nikkunsmaw fl-Ewropa. It-Turiżmu huwa mod ieħor ta' kif nesportaw l-impatti ambjentali tagħna.

Id-drawwiet tagħna fl-ikel u x-xorb iwasslu għal pressjonijiet ambjentali sinifikanti. Aħna nikkawżaw dawn b'mod dirett billi nivjaġġaw lejn il-ħwienet, naħżnu, nsajjru u niġġeneraw l-iskart. Indirettament, u aktar importanti, jeżistu wkoll l-effetti relatati mal- produzzjoni tal-ikel, l-ipproċessar u l-ġarr.

Aħna nixtru numri dejjem jiżdiedu ta' oġġetti ellettroniċi bħal TVs, DVDs, PCs, laptops, mowbajls, sterjos u apparat tal-kċina u dawn nissostitwuhom aktar frekwentement. Id-djar jammontaw għal 28.8 % tal-elettriku użat fl-Ewropa, u l-konsum tal-elettriku mid-djar qiegħed jikber. Aħna nibnu wkoll djar akbar għal inqas nies filwaqt li nużaw aktar enerġija fi djarna. It-tisħin tal-ispazju għadu l-aktar li juża enerġija fid-djar fl-UE (70 %).  Kull ċittadin Ewropew jarmi medja ta' 520 kg ta' skart tad-dar fis-sena, u din il-figura mistennija li tikber aktar.

L-ivjaġġar bil-karozza u l-avjazzjoni jibqgħu jikbru, u jwasslu għal żieda fil-konsum tal-enerġija u emissjoni tal-gass tal-effett serra. Iż-żieda fit-traffiku tal-karozzi huwa kawża ewlenija ta' tniġġiż tal-arja u jikkawża wkoll problemi ta' storbju fl-ibliet. Ix-xejra tal-lum lejn għixien f'żoni urbani ġodda u b'densità baxxa qed tirriżulta f' firxa urbana u qed tikkawża żieda fil-konsum tal-enerġija, ir-riżorsi, it-trasport u l-art.

It-turiżmu huwa wieħed mis-setturi li l-aktar qed jikbru malajr. L-ivvjaġġar lejn u mid-destinazzjoni ġeneralment isir bil-karozza jew bl-ajruplan. F'destinazzjonijiet turistiċi, il-konsum tal-ilma u l-enerġija, l-użu tal-art u l-ġenerazzjoni ta' skart u ta' ilma mormi kollha qed jiżdiedu.

trans-unit.source: The EEA is the European Union air data centre. The EEA supports the implementation of a number of EU Directives linked to air emissions and air quality. The EEA also contributes to the evaluation of EU air pollution policies and to the development of long-term strategies to improve air quality in Europe. The EEA's work focuses on documenting and assessing air emissions and air quality trends and related policies and measures in Europe.
trans-unit.target: L-EEA hija ċ-ċentru tad-dejta dwar l-arja tal-Unjoni Ewropea. L-EEA tappoġġja l-implimentazzjoni ta' numru ta' Direttivi tal-UE abbinati mal-emissjonijiet fl-arja u l-kwalità tal-arja. L-EEA tikkontribwixxi wkoll għall-evalwazzjoni ta' politiki tal-UE dwar it-tniġġis tal-arja u għall-iżvilupp ta' strateġiji fit-tul sabiex titjieb il-kwalità tal-arja fl-Ewropa. Ix-xogħol tal-EEA jiffoka fuq id-dokumentazzjoni u l-valutazzjoni tal-emissjonijiet tal-arja u tax-xejriet fil-kwalità tal-arja u l-politiki u l-miżuri relatati fl-Ewropa.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/air/eea-activities

source.p: The EEA supports the EU in developing long-term strategies to reduce emissions of air pollutants by providing assessment and information to policy-makers. Our key activities and products include:

ul.li: making available data reported by European countries as part of their reporting obligations under international and European legislation;

annual reports providing information on the most recent data submitted by EU Member States under the EU National Emission Ceilings Directive. The data are made available via the EEA air pollutant emissions data viewer (NEC Directive);

compilation of the European Community’s annual Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution Convention emission inventory and supporting Inventory Report. The data are made available via the EEA air pollutant emissions data viewer (LRTAP Convention);
an emission inventory review process, jointly with the European Monitoring and Evaluation Programme , which assesses the quality of national air pollutant emission inventories;

annual updates of the EMEP/EEA Air Pollutant Emission Inventory Guidebook, which provides methodological guidance for national inventory compilers and researchers who are interested in calculating air pollutant emissions;
indicators on air pollutant emission trends as part of the EEA Core Set of Indicators (CSI).

source.p: The EEA's work on air quality has supported the development and future implementation of the Directive on Ambient Air Quality and Cleaner Air for Europe and existing EU air quality legislation.
Key activities and products include:

ul.li: AirBase, which holds air quality monitoring data and supporting information from Europe’s air quality networks and individual stations measuring ambient air pollution. The AirBase Viewer provides spatial data and station information;
Explore ozone today, which provides daily near-real-time information on ozone pollution across Europe during the summer season;
spatial assessment of air quality in Europe (maps) for key air pollutants;
regular assessments on the status of air pollution in Europe, such as the 2007 report ‘Air pollution in Europe 1990–2004’;

contributions to the EEA’s regular state of the environment reports, including the air quality chapter in the EEA’s 2007 pan-European assessment report 'Europe’s environment — The fourth assessment’ and ‘The European environment — State and outlook 2005’ report;
indicators on air quality as part of the EEA Core Set of Indicators (CSI)

source.p:
The EEA's air and transport group leads the Agency's work in this field. The group works closely with the European Topic Centre on Air and Climate Change (ETC/ACC) and with EEA's country network
(Eionet).

target.h2: Emissjonijiet ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja
target.p: L-EEA tappoġġja lill-UE fl-iżvilupp ta' strateġiji fi-tul sabiex jitnaqqsu l-emissjonijiet ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja billi tipprovdi valutazzjoni u informazzjoni lil min ifassal il-politika. L-attivitajiet u l-prodotti ewlenin tagħna jinkludu:

ul.li: li nagħmlu disponibbli d-dejta rappurtata mill-pajjiżi Ewropej bħala parti mill-obbligi ta' rappurtaġġ tagħhom taħt il-leġiżlazzjoni nazzjonali u Ewropea;

rapporti annwali li jipprovdu informazzjoni dwar l-aktar dejta reċenti mibgħuta mill-Istati Membri tal-UE taħt id-Direttiva tal-Massimi Nazzjonali tal-Emissjononijiet. Id-dejta hija disponibbli permezz tal- werrej tad-dejta tal-EEA dwar l-emissjonijiet ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja (id-Direttiva NEC);

li tiġbor l-inventarju annwnali tal-Kummissjoni Ewropea skont il-Konvenzjoni dwar it-Tniġġis tal-Arja Transkonfinali f’Distanza Kbira u li toffri appoġġ għar- Rapport dwar l-Inventarju. Id-dejta hija disponibbli permezz tal- werrej tad-dejta tal-EEA dwar l-emissjonijiet ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja (id-Direttiva LRTAP);
proċess ta' reviżjoni tal-inventarju, flimkien mal- Programm Ewropew għall-Monitoraġġ u l-Evalwazzjoni , li jivvaluta l-kwalità tal-inventarji nazzjonali tas-sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja;

aġġornamenti annwali tal-ktieb ta' Gwida tal-EMEP/EEA għall-Inventarju tal-Emissjoni ta' Sustanzi li Jniġġsu l-Arja, li jipprovdi gwida metodoloġika għal dawk li jikkumpilaw l-inventarji nazzjonali u għar-riċerkaturi li huma interessati fil-kalkoli tal-emissjonijiet ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja;
indikaturi dwar ix-xejriet tal-emissjoni ta' sustanzi li jniġġsu l-arja bħala parti mis- Sett Ewlieni ta' Indikaturi tal-EEA (CSI).

target.p: Ix-xogħol tal-EEA dwar il-kwalità tal-arja appoġġja l-iżvilupp u l-implimentazzjoni futura tad- Direttiva dwar il-Kwalità tal-Arja fil-madwar u Arja aktar nadifa għall-Ewropa u leġiżlazzjoni eżistenti tal-UE dwar il-kwalità tal-arja.
L-attivitajiet u l-prodotti ewlenin jinkludu:

ul.li: AirBase, li għandha dejta tal-monitoraġġ tal-kwalità tal-arja u informazzjoni relatata min-netwerks tal-kwalità tal-arja tal-Ewropa u stazzjonijiet individwali li jkejlu t-tniġġis tal-arja tal-madwar. Il-Werrej AirBase jipprovdi dejta dwar l-ispazju u informazzjoni dwar l-istazzjon;
Esplora l-ożonu llum, li jipprovdi informazzjoni ta' kuljum kważi fil-ħin li sseħħ, dwar it-tniġġis tal-ożonu fl-Ewropa matul l-istaġun tas-sajf;
valutazzjonijiet tal-ispazju dwar il-kwalità tal-arja fl-Ewropa (mapep) għas-sustanzi ewlenin li jniġġsu l-arja;
valutazzjonijiet regolari dwar l-istat tat-tniġġis tal-arja fl-Ewropa, bħar-rapport tal-2007 'It-tniġġis tal-arja fl-Ewropa bejn l-1990-2004’;

kontribuzzjonijiet għar-rapporti regolari tal-EEA dwar l-istat tal-ambjent, inkluż il-kapitlu dwar il-kwalità tal-arja fir-rapport ta' valutazzjoni pan-Ewropea tal-EEA fl-2007 'L-Ambjent fl-Ewropa - Ir-raba' valutazzjoni ' u r-rapport 'L-ambjent Ewropew - l-Istat u l-prospetti 2005 ' ;
indikaturi dwar il-kwalità tal-arja bħala parti mis- Sett Ewlieni tal-Indikaturi tal-EEA (CSI)

target.p:
Il-grupp tal-EEA dwar l-arja u t-trasport imexxi x-xogħol tal-Aġenzija f'dan il-qasam. Il-grupp jaħdem mill-qrib maċ- Ċentru Topiku Ewropew dwar l-Arja u l-Bidla fil-Klima (ETC/ACC) u man- netwerk tal-pajjiżi tal-EEA
(Eionet).

trans-unit.source: Sustainable household consumption is not yet backed by well-defined policy objectives and measures. Changing people's behaviour is difficult and often politically sensitive. Some policy instruments, such as eco-labelling, environmental taxes or subsidies, raising awareness, and product standards, are already used to change consumption patterns in a more sustainable direction. Increasingly, the focus is on the sustainable consumption and production policies. This is a common challenge where all players, including public authorities, business and consumers, come together to take responsibility and implement actions. Solutions are being looked for at the global level: in Europe and other world regions, as well as nationally and locally.
trans-unit.target: Il-konsum sostenibbli tad-djar għadu mhux appoġġat b'objettiv u miżuri politiċi ddefiniti sewwa. Li tbiddel l-imġieba tan-nies huwa diffiċli u ħafna drabi politikament sensittiv. Xi strumenti politiċi bħall-ittikkettar ekoloġiku, it-taxxi jew is-sussidji ambjentali, il-ħolqien ta' kuxjenza, u l-istandards għall-prodotti, diġà huma użati sabiex jagħtu direzzjoni aktar sostenibbli lill-mudelli ta' konsum. Kull ma jmur l-attenzjoni fuq il-politiki ta' konsum u produzzjoni sostenibbli qed tiżdied. Din hija sfida komuni fejn il-partijiet kollha, inklużi l-awtoritajiet pubbliċi, in-negozji u l-konsumaturi jingħaqdu sabiex jieħdu responsabilità u jimplimentaw l-azzjonijiet. Qed jitfitxxu soluzzjonijiet fil-livell globali: fl-Ewropa u f'reġjuni oħra tad-dinja, kif ukoll nazzjonalment u lokalment.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/households/policy-context

source.p: The role of public authorities is to provide the framework within which business and consumers can operate — using legal, market-based information and other tools. Businesses face the challenge of producing goods and services that are sustainable over their entire life-cycle. The challenge for consumers is to choose sustainable goods and services — as far as these are known, available or affordable.

Sustainable consumption makes part of the Agenda 21, which was adopted at the Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) held in Rio de Janeiro in 1992. At the 2002 World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg, an agreement was reached to develop a framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production (SCP) and in 2003, the global 'Marrakech Process' was started to develop this framework. In 2010 and 2011, the United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development will review this global process to achieve more sustainable consumption and production.

In order to raise awareness, as well as to influence consumer behaviour and improve the environmental performance of products and services, there are several policy instruments in current use.  Examples include the eco-labelling of food products, such as organic foods, and the energy-efficiency labelling of household appliances. Energy consumption is also tackled by other EU policies, e.g. the EU Action Plan for Energy Efficiency, the strategy to reduce CO2 emissions from new cars and vans, and the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive.

Sustainable consumption and production is now one of the seven key challenges of the renewed EU Sustainable Development Strategy. The European Commission is expected to issue a Sustainable Consumption and Production (SCP) Action plan in 2008.

A number of EEA member countries have adopted sustainable consumption and production action plans of their own or address those issues as part of their sustainable development strategies. Other countries are dealing with these challenges using other names or headings. Sometimes consumption issues are tackled via sectoral policies such as environment, transport, energy or agricultural policies. Many initiatives and actions are also taken at the regional and local level, for example within regional sustainable development strategies and the Agenda 21 processes.

li.a: United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development

ul.li: Environment Directorate-General of the European Commission

target.p: Ir-rwol tal-awtoritajiet pubbliċi huwa li jipprovdu qafas li fih jistgħu joperaw in-negozji u l-konsumaturi&nbsp:- bl-użu ta' informazzjoni legali bbażata fuq is-suq u għodod oħra. In-Negozji qed jiffaċċjaw l-isfida biex jipproduċu oġġetti u servizzi li huma sostenibbli tul iċ-ċiklu kollha tal-ħajja tagħhom. L-isfida għall-konsumaturi hija li jagħżlu oġġetti u servizzi sostenibbli - sakemm dawn ikunu magħrufa, disponibbli u li jkollhom il-mezzi biex jixtruhom.

Il-konsum sostenibbli jifforma parti mill- Aġenda 21, li kienet adottata fil-Konferenza tal-Ġnus Magħquda dwar l-Ambjent u l-Iżvilupp (UNCED) li saret f'Rio de Janeiro fl-1992. Waqt is- Summit Dinji tal-2002 dwar l-Iżvilupp Sostenibbli f'Johannesburg, intlaħaq ftehim sabiex jiġi żviluppat qafas ta' programmi dwar il-konsum u l-produzzjoni sostenibbli (SCP) u fl-2003, il-'Proċess Marrakech' globali beda jiżviluppa dan il-qafas. Fl-2010 u l-2011, il-Kumissjoni dwar l-Iżvilupp sostenibbli tal-Ġnus Magħquda se tirrevedi dan il-proċess globali sabiex tikseb konsum u produzzjoni aktar sostenibbli.

Sabiex tqajjem kuxjenza, kif ukoll biex tinfluwenza l-imġieba tal-konsumaturi u ttejjeb l-eżekuzzjoni ambjentali tal-prodotti u s-servizz, hemm diversi strumenti politiċi li qed jintużaw bħalissa.  Eżempji jinkludu l-ittikkettar ekoloġiku tal-prodotti tal-ikel, bħall-ikel organiku, u l-ittikkettar skond l-effiċjenza tal-enerġija tal-apparat tad-dar. Il-konsum tal-enerġija huwa indirizzat ukoll minn linji poltiċi oħra tal-UE, eż. il-Pjan ta' Azzjoni tal-UE għall-Effiċjenza fl-Enerġija, l-istrateġija biex jitnaqqsu l-emissjonijiet ta' CO2 minn karozzi u vannijiet ġodda, u d-Direttiva dwar il-Prestazzjoni tal-Enerġija tal-Bini.

Il-konsum u l-produzzjoni sostenibbli issa hija waħda mis-seba' sfidi ewlenin tal- Istrateġija tal-UE għall-Iżvilupp Sostenibbli riveduta. Il-Kummissjoni Ewropea fl-2008 mistennija toħroġ pjan ta' Azzjoni dwar il-Konsum u l-Produzzjoni Sostenibbli (SCP).
target.h2: Il-linji politiċi nazzjonali, reġjonali u lokali
target.p: Numru ta' pajjiżi tal-EEA adottaw pjanijiet ta' azzjoni individwali dwar il-konsum u l-produzzjoni sostenibbli jew jindirizzaw dwak il-kwistjonijiet bħala parti mill-istrateġiji tagħhom għall-Iżvilupp sostenibbli. Pajjiżi oħra qed jitrattaw ma' dawn l-isfidi bl-użu ta' ismijiet u titoli oħra. Xi drabi, l-kwistjonijiet tal-konsum huma trattati permezz ta' linji politiċi settorjali bħal-linji politiċi dwar l-ambjent, l-enerġija jew l-agrikultura. Ħafna inizjattivi u azzjonijiet jittieħdu wkoll fil-livell reġjonali u lokali, pereżempju fi ħdan strateġiji reġjonali għall-iżvilupp sostenibbli jew il-proċessi tal-Aġenda 21.

div.p: The Earths ecological systems are of a dynamic character and reflect climatic conditions and geological, biochemical and biological processes over time.

Five major biodiversity extinction events have been recorded since the earliest times in the planet history. Each of them has led to profound shifts in the life forms on earth. Scientists suggest that we might be now on the brink of a sixth biodiversity crisis, due to human activities.
Read the SNAPSHOT above for a summary of biodiversity issues, or the FULL ARTICLE.
Is-sistemi ekoloġiċi tad-dinja huma ta' karattru dinamiku u jirriflettu l-kundizzjonijiet klimatiċi u ġeoloġiċi, il-proċessi biokimiku u bijoloġiċi fuq medda ta' żmien.

Ġew irreġistrati ħames ġrajjiet ewlenin ta' estinzjoni ta' biodiversità mill-ewwel żminijiet fl-istorja tal-pjaneta. Kull waħda minnhom wasslet għal bidliet profondi fil-forom ta' ħajja fid-dinja. Ix-xjenzati jissuġġerixxu li issa nistgħu nkunu fix-xifer tas-sitt kriżi fil-bijodiversità, minħabba l-attivitajiet tal-bniedem.
Għal sommarju dwar il-kwistjonijiet ta' bijodiveristà aqra is-SNAPSHOT hawn fuq, jew l-ARTIKOLU SĦIĦ.

trans-unit.source: For policy-makers and individuals alike, it is important to know which consumption and production areas have the highest impact on the environment, as well as which policies and choices can really make a difference. The work of EEA focuses on the development of indicators and assessment of environmental impacts together with policy analysis. Our work aims at supporting the European Commission, Parliament and Council, the United Nations, national governments and other stakeholders in finding the most effective paths to sustainable consumption.
trans-unit.target: Għal min ifissal il-politika kif ukoll għall-individwi, tajjeb li jkunu jafu liema oqsma ta' konsum u produzzjoni għandhom l-ogħla impatt fuq l-ambjent, kif ukoll liema linji politiċi u għażliet jistgħu tabilħaqq jagħmlu differenza. Ix-xogħol tal-EEA jiffoka fuq l-iżvilupp ta' indikaturi u valutazzjonijiet ta' impatti ambjentali flimkien ma' analiżi tal-politika. Ix-xogħol tagħna għandu l-għan li jappoġġja lill-Kummissjoni Ewropea, lill-Parlament u lill-Kunsill, lill-Ġnus Magħquda, lill-gvernijiet nazzjonali u lil partijiet interessati oħra sabiex isibu l-aktar toroq effettivi għall-konsum sostenibbli.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/households/eea-activities

ul.li: Several indicators are already available showing which trends in consumption contribute to the environmental impacts of consumption;
Work is in process to develop a framework and indicators for sustainable consumption (and production) in Europe.

h2.strong: Impacts of consumption (and production) in Europe

ul.li: Analyses of  the environmental pressures from consumption (and production);

Assessment of the environmental impacts of household consumption, either in dedicated reports or as part of the 'state of the environment' reports, e.g. the  Europe's environment — The fourth assessment (2007);

Support to non-EU regions in finding possible pathways to sustainable consumption (and production), e.g. analysis of the situation in South-East Europe and Eastern Europe, as well as in the Caucasus and Central Asia in a joint UNEP/EEA report (2007).
Organisation of conferences and workshops, e.g. the conference 'Time for action: towards sustainable consumption and production in Europe' in September 2007;
Collection of information and analysis of national policies of the EEA member countries, e.g. in the report 'Time for action — towards sustainable consumption and production in Europe'.

source.p: The Group for Sustainable Consumption and Production leads the Agency's work in this field, and is supported by the European Topic Centre on Resource and Waste Management (ETC/RWM) (Internet: http://waste.eionet.europa.eu/). Specific aspects of household consumption are also covered by EEA activities in other areas, e.g. climate change and energy, transport and agriculture.

ul.li: Bosta indikaturi diġà huma disponibbli u juru liema xejriet fil-konsum jikkontribwixxu għall-impatti ambjentali tal-konsum;
Qed isir xogħol sabiex jiġu żviluppati qafas u indikaturi għall-konsum sostenibbli (u l-produzzjoni) fl-Ewropa.
Analiżi tal-  pressjonijiet ambjentali mill-konsum (u l-produzzjoni);

Valutazzjonijiet tal-impatti ambjentali tal-konsum tad-djar, jew f'rapporti ddedikati jew bħala parti mir-rapporti dwar 'l-istat tal-ambjent', eż. l-  ambjent fl-Ewropa - Ir-raba' valutazzjoni (2007);

L-appoġġ lir-reġjuni mhux tal-UE sabiex isisbu t-toroq possibbli għall-konsum sostenibbli (u l-produzzjoni), eż. analiżi tas-sitwazzjoni fix-Xlokk tal-Ewropa u fl-Ewropa tal-Lvant, kif ukoll fil-Kawkasu u fl-Ażja Ċentrali f' rapport konġunt bejn l-UNEP u l-EEA (2007).
L-organizzazzjoni ta' konferenzi u workshops, eż. il-konferenza 'Żmien għal azzjoni: lejn konsum u produzzjoni sostenibbli fl-Ewropa' f'Settembru 2007;
Il-ġbir ta' informazzjoni u analiżi tal-linji politiċi nazzjonali tal-pajjiżi membri tal-EEA, eż.  fir-rapport 'Żmien għal azzjoni - lejn konsum u produzzjoni sostenibbli fl-Ewropa'

target.p: Il-Grupp għall-Konsum u l-Produzzjoni Sostenibbli jmexxi x-xogħol tal-Aġenzija f'dan il-qasam, u huwa sostnut miċ-Ċentru Tematiku Ewropew dwar l-Immaniġġjar tar-Riżorsi u l-Iskart (ETC/RWM) (Internet: http://waste.eionet.europa.eu/). L-aspetti speċifiċi tal-konsum tad-djar huma wkoll koperti mill-attivitajiet tal-EEA f'oqsma oħrajn, eż. it-tibdil fil-klima u l-enerġija, it-trasport u l-agrikoltura.

trans-unit.source: A clean environment is essential for human health and well-being. However, the interactions between the environment and human health are highly complex and difficult to assess. This makes the use of the precautionary principle particularly useful. The best-known health impacts are related to ambient air pollution, poor water quality and insufficient sanitation. Much less is known about the health impacts of hazardous chemicals. Noise is an emerging environment and health issue. Climate change, depletion of stratospheric ozone, loss of biodiversity, and land degradation can also affect human health.
trans-unit.target: Ambjent nadif huwa essenzjali għas-saħħa u l-benesseri tal-bniedem. Madankollu, l-interazzjonijiet bejn l-ambjent u s-saħħa tal-bniedem huma kumplessi ħafna u diffiċli biex jiġu evalwati. Dan jagħmel l-użu tal-prinċipju ta' prekawzjoni partikolarment utli. L-impatti fuq is-saħħa l-aktar magħrufa huma relatati mat-tniġġiż tal-atmosfera, kwalità ħażina ta' ilma u sanità insuffiċjenti. Ħafna inqas hu magħruf dwar l-impatti tal-kimiċi perikolużi fuq is-saħħa. L-istorbju huwa kwistjoni emerġenti għas-saħħa u l-ambjent. Il-bidla fil-klima, it-tħassir tal-ożonu stratosferiku, it-telf ta' biodiversità, u d-degradazzjoni tal-art jistgħu ukoll jaffettwaw saħħet il-bniedem.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/human/about-environment-and-health

source.p: In Europe, the major environment-related health concerns are related to outdoor and indoor air pollution, poor water quality, poor sanitation and hazardous chemicals. The related health impacts include respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, cancer, asthma and allergies, as well as reproductive and neurodevelopmental disorders.

Fine particulate matter and ground-level ozone are the main threats to human health from air pollution. The EU's Clean Air for Europe (CAFE) programme estimated a total of 348 000 premature deaths per year due to exposure to fine particles (PM2.5). At this level of exposure, average life expectancy is reduced by approximately one year.

The EU Green Paper on noise exposure states that around 20 % of the EU’s population suffer from noise levels that health experts consider to be unacceptable, i.e. which can lead to annoyance, sleep disturbance and adverse health effects.
Transport, especially in urban areas, is one of the key contributors to human exposure to air pollution and noise.

Much less is known about the health impacts of chemicals. There is growing concern about the effects of exposure to mixtures of chemicals at low levels and for long periods over our life-time, in particular during early childhood and pregnancy.

Persistent chemicals with long-term effects, such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and chlorofluorocarbons CFCs, and those used in long-life structures — for example construction materials — may present risks even after their production has been phased out.

Many pollutants known to affect human health are gradually coming under regulatory control. However, there are emerging issues for which environmental pathways and effects on health are as yet poorly understood. Examples are electromagnetic fields (EMF), pharmaceuticals in the environment and some infectious diseases (the spreading of which may be affected by climate change). The development of ‘early warning’ systems should be encouraged to shorten the time between detection of a potential hazard and a policy action or intervention.

Human health has always been threatened by natural hazards such as storms, floods, fires, landslides and droughts. Their consequences are being worsened by a lack of preparedness and by human actions such as deforestation, climate change and biodiversity loss.

target.p: Fl-Ewropa, il-preokkupazzjonijiet ewlenin ta' saħħa relatati mal-ambjent huma relatati mat-tniġġis tal-arja fuq barra u fuq ġewwa, il-kwalità fqira tal-ilma, il-livell baxx ta' sanità u l-kimiċi perikolużi. L-impatti ta' saħħa relatati jinkludu mard respiratorju u kardjovaskulari, il-kanċer, l-ażma u l-allerġija, kif ukoll disturbi riproduttivi u fl-iżvilupp newroloġiku.

Il-materja tal-partiċella fina u l-ożonu fil-livell tal-art huma t-theddid ewlieni għas-saħħa umana mit- tniġġis tal-arja. Il-programm tal-UE dwar Arja Nadifa għall-Ewropa (CAFE) ħareġ stima ta' total ta' 348 000 mewt prematura kull sena minħabba l-espożizzjoni għall-partiċelli fini (PM2.5). F'dan il-livell ta' espożizzjoni, it-tul ta' ħajja medja titnaqqas b'madwar sena.

Il- Green Paper tal-UE dwar l-espożizzjoni għall-istorbju tiddikkjara li madwar 20 % tal-popolazzjoni tal-UE ssofri minn livelli ta' storbju li l-esperti tas-saħħa jqisu bħala inaċċettabbli, jiġifieri li jistgħu jwasslu għal fastidju, interruzzjoni fl-irqad u effetti negattivi fuq is-saħħa.
It-trasport, espeċjalment f'żoni urbani, huwa wieħed mill-kontributuri ewlenin għall-espożizzjoni tal-bniedem għat-tniġġis tal-arja u l-istorbju.

Ħafna inqas hu magħruf dwar l-impatti tal-kimiċi fuq is-saħħa. Hemm tħassib li qed jiber dwar l-effetti tal-espożizzjoni għal taħlitiet ta' kimiċi f'livell baxx u għal perijodi twal f'ħajjitna, b'mod partikolari waqt il-bidu tat-tfulija u fit-tqala.

Kimiċi persistenti b'effetti fit-tul, bħall-polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) u l-chlorofluorocarbons CFCs, u dawk użati fi strutturi li jdumu għal ħafna żmien - per eżempju materjal tal-kostruzzjoni - jistgħu jippreżentaw riskji anke wara li l-produzzjoni tagħhom tkun waqfet b'mod gradwali.

Ħafna sustanzi li jniġġsu magħrufa li jaffettwaw is-saħħa umana, gradwalment qed jiġu taħt kontroll regolatorju. Madankollu, hemm kwistjinijiet emerġenti li t-toroq ambjentali għalihom u l-effetti għas-saħħa għadhom mhux mifhuma sew. l-eżempji huma l-oqsma elettromanjetiċi (EMF), il-farmaċewtiċi fl-ambjent u xi mard li jittieħed (li l-firxa tagħhom tista' tkun affettwata mill-bidla fil-klima). L-iżvilupp ta' 'sistemi ta' twissija kmieni' għandhom jiġu mħeġġa sabiex jitnaqqas il-ħin bejn l-iskoperta ta' periklu potenzjali u l-azzjoni jew l-intervent politiku.

Is-saħħa tal-bniedem dejjem kienet mhedda mill-perikli naturali bħall-maltempati, għargħar, nirien, valangi u nixfiet. Il-konsegwenzi ta' dawn qed jiħżienu minħabba n-nuqqas ta' preparazzjoni u minħabba l-azzjonijiet umani bħad-deforestazzjoni, il-bidla fil-klima u t-telf ta' biodiversità.

trans-unit.source: Policy responses to environment-related health issues in Europe at international, regional and national levels are improving. Recent international action plans often focus on children. However, for many health hazards, actions lag well behind policies.
trans-unit.target: Ir-risposti politiċi għall-kwistjonijiet ta' saħħa relatati mal-ambjent fl-Ewropa fil-livell internazzjonali, reġjonali u nazzjonali qed jitjiebu. Il-pjanijiet ta' azzjoni internazzjonali reċenti ħafna drabi jiffokaw fuq it-tfal. Madankollu, għal ħafna perikli ta' saħħa, l-azzjonijiet jaqgħu lura sew wara l-politiki.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/human/policy-context

source.p: At the Fourth Ministerial Conference on Environment and Health in 2004, the World Health Organisation (WHO) adopted the Children's Environment and Health Action Plan for Europe (CEHAPE). WHO also reaffirmed the need for an environment and health information system based on indicators, and formulated recommendations on public health responses to extreme weather events and the health consequences of climate change.

In 2007, the WHO intergovernmental midterm review (IMR) evaluated progress in implementing the commitments of the Fourth Ministerial Conference. The first outputs of the Environment and Health Information System (EHIS) were presented and formed the basis for an assessment of the current status of children's health and the environment in Europe.

In the countries of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe  (UNECE) region, adoption of the Protocol on Water and Health to the 1992 Convention on Protection and Use of Transboundary Watercourses and International Lakes marked progress in addressing environment and health issues related to water in an integrated manner.
Health is one of the priorities of the EU Sustainable Development Strategy. Environmental quality and the link to human health are highlighted in the EU 6th environment action programme (6EAP).
Four pieces of legislation provide the foundation to the EU’s approach to limiting environmental threats to human health:

ul.li: the Water Framework Directive
the Regulation concerning the Registration, Evaluation and Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH)
the proposal for a directive on ambient air quality and cleaner air for Europe
the proposal for a framework directive on pesticides.

source.p: The European Environment and Health Strategy (2003) and the European environment and health action plan 2004–2010 (2004) have four priority diseases:

ul.li: childhood cancer
asthma and allergy
neurodevelopmental disorders
endocrine-disrupting effects.

source.p: European processes aiming at the integration of policies are particularly relevant for environment and health.
More information: the European Commission's European Environment and Health Homepage

target.p: Waqt ir-Raba' Konferenza Ministerjali dwar l-Ambjent u s-Saħħa fl-2004, l- Organizzazzjoni Dinjija tas-Saħħa (WHO) adottat il-Pjan ta' Azzjoni għall-Ewropa dwar l-Ambjent u s-Saħħa tat-Tfal (CEHAPE). Il-WHO reġgħet affermat ukoll il-ħtieġa għal sistema ta' informazzjoni dwar l-ambjent u s-saħħa ibbażata fuq l-indikaturi, u fformulat rakkomandazzjonijiet dwar ir-reazzjoni tas-saħħa pubblika għal każijiet ta' temp estrem u l-konsegwenzi tal-bidla tal-klima fuq is-saħħa.

Fl-2007, ir-reviżjoni intergovernattiva ta' nofs it-terminu tal-WHO (IMR) evalwat il-progress fl-implimentazzjoni tal-obbligi tar-Raba' Konferenza Ministerjali. L-ewwel riżultati tas-Sistema ta' Informazzjoni dwar l-Ambjent u s-Saħħa (EHIS) kienu ppreżentati u ffurmaw il-bażi għal valutazzjoni tal-istat preżenti tas-saħħa u l-ambjent tat-tfal fl-Ewropa.

Fil-pajjiżi tar-reġjun tal- Kummissjoni Ekonomika tal-Ġnus Magħquda għall-Ewropa  (UNECE), l-adozzjoni tal-Protokoll dwar l-Ilma u s-Saħħa tal-Konvenzjoni tal-1992 dwar il-Protezzjoni u l-Użu tal-Kanali tal-Ilma Transkonfinali u x-Xmajjar Internazzjonali immarkat progress fl-indirizz tal-kwistjonijiet ta' saħħa u ambjent relatati mal-ilma b'mod integrat.

Is-Saħħa hija waħda mill-prijoritajiet tal-Istrateġija tal-UE għall-Iżvilupp Sostenibbli. Il-kwalità tal-ambjent u r-relazzjoni mas-saħħa tal-bniedem hija ssottolineata fis- 6programm ta' azzjoni ambjentali (6EAP).
Erba' atti leġiżlattivi jipprovdu l-pedament tal-approċċ tal-UE sabiex tillimita t-theddid ambjentali għas-saħħa tal-bniedem:

ul.li: Id-Direttiva Qafas dwar l-Ilma
Ir-Regolament dwar ir-Reġistrazzjoni, l-Evalwazzjoni u l-Awtorizzazzjoni u r-Restrizzjoni tal-Kimiċi (REACH)
il-proposta għal direttiva dwar il-kwalità tal-arja ambjentali u arja aktar nadifa għall-Ewropa
il-proposta għal direttiva qafas dwar il-pestiċidi.

target.p: L-Istrateġija Ewropea dwar l-Ambjent u s-Saħħa (2003) u l-pjan ta' azzjoni Ewropew dwar l-ambjent u s-saħħa bejn l-2004 u l-2010 (2004) għandhom erba' mardiet ta' prijorità:

ul.li: il-kanċer fit-tfal
l-ażma u l-allerġija
id-diżsturbi fl-iżvilupp newroloġiku
l-effetti ta' diżordni endokrinali.

target.p: Il-proċessi Ewropea li għandhom l-għan li jintegraw il-politiki huma partikolarment relevanti għall-ambjent u s-saħħa.

trans-unit.source: EEA activities are aimed at tracking progress to the goals of the EU Environment and Health Strategy, bridging the gap between science and policy. Activities range from methodological work to assessments and economic valuation of health effects. We work in partnership with the European Commission, the World Health Organisation, other Community agencies, countries and other stakeholders.
trans-unit.target: L-attivitajiet tal-EEA huma mmirati biex jikkumparaw il-progress mal-miri tal-Istrateġija tal-UE dwar l-Ambjent u s-Saħħa, biex jitnaqqas id-distakk bejn ix-xjenza u l-politika. L-attivitajiet ivarjaw minn xogħol metodoloġiku għal valutazzjonijiet u valutazzjoni ekonomika tal-effetti fuq is-saħħa. Aħna naħdmu flimkein mal-Kummissjoni Ewropea, l-Organizzazzjoni Dinjija tas-Saħħa, ma' aġenziji oħra tal-Komunità, mal-pajjiżi u ma' partijiet interessati oħra.

source.p: Work focuses on the following:

ul.li: The development of methodologies to assess the impacts of the environment on health, taking into account the complexity of the cause and effect chains;
Approaches to evaluate evidence for action;
Improvement of access to information on environment and health impacts (including chemicals) and their spatial distribution in the context of the Shared Environmental Information System (SEIS);
Support to the European Environment and Health Information System;
Assessment of the link between climate change and health, within the scope of the update of the 2004 report ‘Assessment of impacts of Europe’s changing climate’;
Economic valuation of environment and health impacts.

Approċċi biex tiġi vvalutata l-evidenza għall-azzjoni;

Il-valutazzjoni ekonomika tal-impatti ambjentali u fuq is-saħħa.

trans-unit.target: Dwar l-iskart u r-riżorsi ta' materjal
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/waste/about-waste-and-material-resources

trans-unit.source: The European economy is based on a high level of resource consumption. This includes raw materials (such as metals, construction minerals or wood), energy and land. The main driving forces of Europe's resource consumption are economic growth, technological developments and changing consumption and production patterns. About one third of resources used are turned into waste and emissions. Around four tonnes of waste per capita are generated every year in the EEA member countries. Every European citizen on average throws away 520 kg of household waste per year, and this figure is expected to increase.
trans-unit.target: L-ekonomija Ewropea hija bbażata fuq livell għoli ta' konsum ta' riżorsi. Dan jinkludi l-materja prima (bħall-metalli, il-minerali jew l-injam għall-kostruzzjoni), l-enerġija u l-art. Il-forzi ewlenin li jżidu l-konsum tar-riżorsi tal-Ewropa huma t-tkabbir ekonomiku, l-iżviluppi teknoloġiċi u l-mudelli ta' konsum u produzzjoni li qed jinbidlu. Madwar terz tar-riżorsi wżati huma mibdula fi skart u emissjonijiet. Madwar erba' tunnellati ta' skart per capita jiġi ġġenerat kull sena fil-pajjiżi membri tal-EEA. Kull ċittadin Ewropew jarmi medja ta' 520 kg ta' skart domestiku fis-sena, u din il-figura mistennija tikber.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/waste/about-waste-and-material-resources

source.p: In the EU-15, use of materials has changed little over the past two decades, and remains at about 15–16 tonnes per capita per year. However, this number varies considerably from country to country, from some 12 tonnes per capita in Italy to 38 tonnes per capita in Finland. Construction materials have the largest share in this, followed by fossil fuels and biomass. Efficiency of resource use is several times higher in the EU-15 than in the new EU Member States or the countries of South-eastern Europe. Projections to 2020 indicate that resource use in the EU will continue to increase.

Resource use is also increasing in other regions of the world. This is partly due to increased consumption of goods and services in Europe, often based on resources extracted from these other regions.

div.p: The EU aims to 'improve resource efficiency to reduce the overall use of non-renewable natural resources and the related environmental impacts of raw materials use, thereby using renewable natural resources at a rate that does not exceed their regeneration capacity'  (Renewed EU Sustainable Development Strategy, 2006).

source.p: Europe's high resource consumption puts pressure on the environment both within Europe and in other regions of the world. These pressures include depletion of non-renewable resources, intensive use of renewable resources, transportation, high emissions to water, air and soil from mining activities as well as production, consumption and waste generation. It is generally accepted that there are physical limits to the continued growth of resource use. Housing, food and mobility account for the largest share of resource use and environmental pressures.

Waste disposal has the potential to cause a number of impacts on health and the environment, including emissions to air, surface water and groundwater, depending on how it is managed. Waste also represents a loss of natural resources (such as the metals or other recyclable materials it contains, or its potential as an energy source). Therefore, sound management of waste can protect public health and the quality of the environment whilst supporting conservation of natural resources.

The largest waste streams in Europe originate from construction and demolition, along with manufacturing activities. Most EU municipal waste is still sent to landfill (45 %). However, more and more municipal waste is recycled or composted (37 %), or incinerated with energy recovery (18 %).

target.p: Fl-UE-15, l-użu ta' materjali ftit inbidel matul dawn l-aħħar żewġ deċennji, u jibqa' f'madwar 15-16-il tunnellata per capita fis-sena. Madankollu, dan in-numru jvarja minn pajjiż għall-ieħor, minn madwar 12-il tunnellata per capita fl-Italja għal 38 tunnellata per capita fil-Finlandja. Il-materjali ta' kostruzzjoni għandhom l-akbar sehem f'dan, segwiti mill-fjuwils fossili u l-bijomassa. L-effiċjenza fl-użu tar-riżorsi hija ħafna akbar fl-UE-15 milli fl- Istati Membri l-ġodda tal-UE jew fil-pajjiżi tax-Xlokk tal-Ewropa. Il-projezzjonijiet sal-2020 jindikaw li l-użu tar-riżorsi fl-UE se jkompli jikber.

L-użu tar-riżorsi f'reġjuni oħra fid-dinja qed jikber ukoll. Parzjalment dan hu minħabba ż-żieda fil-konsum tal-oġġetti u s-servizzi fl-Ewropa, li ħafna drabi jkun ibbażat fuq riżorsi estratti minn dawn ir-reġjuni l-oħra.

div.p: L-UE għandha l-għan li 'ttejjeb l-effiċjenza tar-riżorsi sabiex tnaqqas l-użu globali ta' riżorsi naturali li ma jiġġeddux u l-impatti ambjentali relatati tal-użu tal-materja prima, b'hekk jintużaw riżorsi naturali li jiġġeddu f'rata li ma taqbiżx il-kapaċità tagħhom ta' riġenerazzjoni'  (L-Istrateġija mġedda tal-UE dwar l-Iżvilupp Sostenibbli , 2006).

target.p: Il-konsum għoli ta' riżorsi fl-Ewropa jpoġġi pressjoni fuq l-ambjent kemm fi ħdan l-Ewropa kif ukoll f'reġjuni oħra tad-dinja. Dawn il-pressjonijiet jinkludu l-qerda ta' riżorsi li ma jiġġeddux, l-użu intensiv ta' riżorsi li jiġġeddu, it-trasport, l-emissjonijiet għolja fl-ilma, fl-arja u fil-ħamrija minn attivitajiet fil-barrieri kif ukoll mill-produzzjoni, l-konsum u l-ġenerazzjoni tal-iskart. Ġeneralment hu aċċettat li hemm limiti fiżiċi għat-tkabbir kontinwu tal-użu tar-riżorsi. Id-djar, l-ikel u l-mobilità jammontaw għall-akbar sehem fl-użu ta' riżorsi u fil-pressjonijiet ambjentali.

Ir-rimi ta' skart għandu l-potenzjal li jikkawża numru ta' impatti fuq is-saħħa u l-ambjent, inkluż l-emissjonijiet fl-arja, fl-ilma tal-wiċċ u tal-art, skont kif ikun immaniġġjat. L-iskart jirappreżenta wkoll telf ta' riżorsi naturali (bħall-metalli jew materjal riċiklabbli ieħor li fih, jew il-potenzjal tiegħu bħala sors ta' enerġija). Għalhekk, l-immaniġġjar sewwa tal-iskart jista' jipproteġġi s-saħħa pubblika u l-kwalità tal-ambjent filwaqt li jappoġġja l-konservazzjoni tar-riżorsi naturali.

Il-maġġoranza tal-iskart li ġej mill-Ewropa joriġina mill-kostruzzjoni u t-twaqqigħ ta' bini, fl-imkien mal-attivitajiet ta' manifattura. Ħafna skart muniċipali tal-UE xorta jintbagħat f'landfill (45 %). Madankollu, aktar u aktar skart muniċipali huwa rriċiklat jew magħmul kompost (37 %), jew maħruq bl-enerġija rkuprata (18 %).

trans-unit.source: EU policies increasingly emphasise resource use and waste, in particular the EU Sustainable Development Strategy (SDS) and the sixth environment action programme (6EAP). The 6EAP expressly calls for 'breaking the linkages between economic growth and resource use'. In 2007, an International Panel for Sustainable Resource Management was established through cooperation between UNEP and the European Commission.
trans-unit.target: Il-politiki tal-UE dejjem qed ikomplu jenfasizzaw fuq l-użu ta' riżorsi u l-iskart, b'mod partikolari l-Istrateġija tal-UE dwar l-Iżvilupp Sostenibbli (SDS) u s-sitt programm ta' azzjoni ambjentali (6EAP). Is-6EAP b'mod ċar jitlob għall-'ksur tar-relazzjonijiet bejn it-tkabbir ekonomiku u l-użu ta' riżorsi'. Fl-2007, twaqqaf Pànel Internazzjonali għall-Immaniġġjar Sostenibbli tar-Riżorsi permezz ta' kooperazzjoni bejn l-UNEP u l-Kummissjoni Ewropea.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/waste/policy-context

source.p: Almost every European Community policy affects the use and management of natural resources. Among the most important are the common agricultural policy, the common fisheries policy, the regional development policy, and the transport and energy policies. A number of cross-cutting environmental strategies address the sustainable use and management of resources, including the Sustainable Development Strategy, the 6th environment action programme, and the 2005 thematic strategies on the prevention and recycling of waste and on the sustainable use of natural resources.

The ongoing policy debate shows the need for better integration of environment- and resource-related considerations into sectoral and other policy areas. Some of the questions outstanding revolve around how to estimate the environmental impacts of resource use, what priority areas or specific resources should be the focus of policy intervention, and how to set targets and measure progress in sustainable use and management of resources.

As gains in technical efficiency are often offset by more widespread consumption, it is unlikely that resource use and waste generation can be reduced by technological improvements alone. The sustainability of current lifestyles and consumption patterns may have to be critically reviewed and technology has to be combined with other policy instruments.

Whereas EU policies on resources are still evolving, waste policies both in the EU and in individual EU Member States have been progressively put in place since the 1970s. The EU's current waste policy is based on the 'waste hierarchy'. This first aims at waste prevention, then at reducing waste disposal through re-use, recycling and other waste recovery operations. This hierarchy is likely to be strengthened by the amended Waste Framework Directive currently under revision, and by the thematic strategy on the prevention and recycling of waste.

The main waste treatment activities are regulated by the Landfill Directive, the Waste Incineration Directive and the IPPC Directive. For some special waste streams such as packaging waste, end-of-life vehicles and waste electrical and electronic equipment, the principle of the waste hierarchy has been transformed, for example by the introduction of concrete targets for recycling.

A life-cycle approach in policy-making ensures that impacts are assessed from cradle to grave, and that environmental impacts are not simply hidden by moving them to different countries or different stages of production or consumption.

target.p: Kważi kull politika tal-Komunità Ewropea taffettwa l-użu u l-immaniġġjar tar-riżorsi naturali. Fost l-aktar importanti hemm il-politika komuni dwar l-agrikoltura, il-politika komuni dwar is-sajd, il-politika dwar l-iżvilupp reġjonali, u l-politiki dwar it-trasport u l-enerġija. Numru ta' strateġiji ambjentali traversi jindirizzaw l-użu u l-immaniġġjar sostenibbli tar-riżorsi inkluż l- Istrateġija għall-Iżvilupp Sostenibbli, is- 6 programm ta' azzjoni ambjentali, u l-istrateġiji tematiċi tal-2005 dwar il- prevenzjoni u r-riċiklaġġ tal-iskart u dwar l- użu sostenibbli tar-riżorsi naturali.

Id-dibattitu politiku li għaddej bħalissa juri l-ħtieġa għall-integrazzjoni aħjar tal-kunsiderazzjonijiet dwar l-ambjent u dawk relatati mar-riżorsi, f'oqsma settorali u f'oqsma politiċi oħra. Ftit mill-mistoqsijiet pendenti jduru madwar kif issir stima tal-impatti ambjentali tal-użu ta' riżorsi, liema oqsma ta' prijorità jew riżorsi speċifiċi għandhom ikunu fiċ-ċentru tal-intervent politiku, u kif jiġu stabbiliti l-miri u jitkejjel il-progress fl-użu u l-immaniġġjar sostenibbli ta' riżorsi.

Waqt li l-kisbiet fl-effiċjenza teknika ħafna drabi huma kkanċellati b'aktar konsum mifrux, huwa improbabbli li l-użu ta' riżorsi u l-ġenerazzjoni tal-iskart jista' jitnaqqas biss bit-titjib teknoloġiku. Is-sostenibilità tal-mudellli tal-istili ta' ħajja u l- konsum preżenti jistgħu jkollhom jiġu riveduti b'mod kritiku u t-teknoloġija trid tkun magħquda ma' strumenti politiċi oħra

Filwaqt li l-politiki tal-UE dwar ir-riżorsi għadhom qed jevolvu, il-politiki dwar l-iskart kemm fl-UE u fl-Istati Membri individwali kienu progressivament implimentati sa mis-snin 70. Il-politika preżenti tal-UE dwar l-iskart hija bbażata fuq il-'ġerarkija tal-iskart'. L-ewwel timmira lejn il-prevenzjoni tal-iskart, imbagħad lejn it-tnaqqis tar-rimi tal-iskart billi jerġa' jintuża, ir-riċiklaġġau operazzjonijiet oħra ta' rkuprar tal-iskart. Din il-ġerarkija probabbli li tissaħħaħ bid- Direttiva Qafas dwar l-Iskart emendata li bħalissa qed tiġi riveduta, u bl- istrateġija tematika għall-prevenzjoni u r-riċiklaġġ tal-iskart.

L-attivitajiet ewlenin tat-trattament tal-iskart huma regolati mid- Direttiva dwar il-Landfills, id- Direttiva dwar il-Ħruq tal-Iskart u d- Direttiva IPPC. Għal skart speċjali bħal skart li ġej mill-ippakkjar, minn vetturi li waslu fl-aħħar u minn apparat elettriku u elettroniku mormi, il-prinċipju tal-ġerarkija tal-iskart ġie ttrasformat, pereżempju bl-introduzzjoni ta' miri konkreti għar-riċiklaġġ.

Approċċ ta' ċiklu tal-ħajja fit-tfassil tal-politika jassigura li l-impatti jkunu vvalutati mill-benniena sal-qabar, u li l-impatti ambjentali mhumiex sempliċement moħbija billi jiġi mċaqilqa għal pajjiżi differenti jew għal stadji differenti tal-produzzjoni jew konsum.

trans-unit.source: EEA's assessments on waste and material resources aim to support the development of policies on sustainable consumption and production, including the implementation of thematic strategies on sustainable use of natural resources and on waste prevention and recycling. Activities include monitoring and development of indicators, evaluation of the effectiveness of waste and resources policies and identification of best practices.
trans-unit.target: Il-valutazzjonijiet tal-EEA dwar l-iskart u r-riżorsi materjali għandhom l-għan li jappoġġjaw l-iżvilupp ta' politiki dwar il-konsum u l-produzzjoni sostenibbli, inkluż l-implimentazzjoni ta' strateġiji tematiċi dwar l-użu sostenibbli tar-riżorsi naturali u dwar il-prevenzjoni tal-iskart u r-riċiklaġġ. L-attivitajiet jinkludu l-monitoraġġ u l-iżvilupp tal-indikaturi, l-evalwazzjoni tal-effikaċja tal-politiki dwar l-iskart u r-riżorsi u l-identifikazzjoni tal-aħjar prattiċi.
trans-unit.note: The context of the source content is available online at http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/waste/eea-activities

source.p: The work of the EEA on waste and material resources includes:

ul.li: periodic assessments and reports on waste and material flows such as the pan-European review Europe's environment — the fourth assessment;
regional overviews of implementation of sustainable consumption and production, and of waste generation and resource use in particular;
support to specific policy priorities, including sustainable use and management of natural resources and the decoupling of economic growth from resource use and waste;
support to member countries in waste reporting (including the Packaging Waste Directive) and material flow accounting;

policy effectiveness studies, e.g. packaging waste management, urban wastewater treatment systems, diversion of waste from landfills, use of economic instruments in resource management; see also Policy instruments.
work on trans-boundary shipments of waste in Europe and the environmental effects of the 'recycling society';
future outlooks and scenarios studies, such as on the development of waste generation and its environmental impacts;
indicators on municipal waste generation and generation and recycling of packaging waste;
country fact sheets on waste management in EU Member States;
an inventory of waste management companies, knowledge centres and installations in the European Environmental Technology Atlas.

source.p: The EEA's sustainable consumption and production group leads the EEA work on waste and material resources. Activities are implemented through cooperation with the EEA's European Topic Centre on Resource and Waste Management (ETC/RWM) and in collaboration with EEA's country network (Eionet). Eurostat is collecting waste data, and from 2008 it will host the environmental data centres on resources, products and waste.

target.p: Ix-xogħol tal-EEA dwar l-iskart u r-riżorsi materjali jinkludi:

ul.li: valutazzjonijiet perjodiċi u rapporti dwar il-flussi ta' skart u materjal bħar-reviżjoni pan-Ewropea 'L-Ambjent fl-Ewropa - Ir-raba' valutazzjoni ';
deskrizzjonijiet reġjonali qosra dwar l-implimentazzjoni tal-konsum u l-produzzjoni sostenibbli, u dwar il-ġenerazzjoni tal-iskart u l-użu ta' riżorsi b'mod partikolari;
appoġġ għal prijoritajiet politiċi speċifiċi, inkluż użu u l-immaniġġjar sostenibbli tar-riżorsi naturali u s-separazzjoni tat-tkabbir ekonomiku mill- użu ta' riżorsi u l-iskart;
appoġġ lill-pajjiżi membri fir- rappurtaġġ tal-iskart (inkluż id-Direttiva dwar l-Iskart mill-Ippakkjar) u l-kontabilità tal-fluss ta' materjal;

studji dwar l-effikaċja tal-politika, eż. l-immaniġġjar tal-iskart mill-ippakkjar, is-sistema tat-trattament tal-ilma urban mormi, id-devjazzjoni tal-iskart mil-landfills, l-użu ta' strumenti ekonomiċi fl-immaniġġjar tar-riżorsi; ara wkoll L-istrumenti politiċi.
xogħol fuq it-trasport transkonfinali bil-baħar tal-iskart fl-Ewropa u l-effetti ambjentali tas-'soċjetà li tirriċikla';
studji dwar il-prospetti u x-xenarji futuri, bħal dwar l-iżvilupp tal-ġenerazzjoni tal-iskart u l-impatti ambjentali tagħha;
indikaturi dwar il-ġenerazzjoni tal-iskart muniċipali u l-ġenerazzjoni u r-riċiklaġġ ta' skart mill-ippakkjar;
karti bil-fatti tal-pajjiżi dwar l-immaniġġjar tal-iskart fl-Istati Membri tal-UE;
inventarju tal-kumpaniji tal-immaniġġjar tal-iskart, ċentri ta' għarfien u installazzjonijiet fl- Atlas Ewropew dwar it-Teknoloġija Ambjentali.

target.p: Il-grupp tal-EEA dawr il-konsum u l-produzzjoni sostenibbli jmexxi x-xogħol tal-EEA dwar l-iskart u r-riżorsi materjali. L-attivitajiet huma implimentati permezz ta' kooperazzjoni maċ-Ċentru Tematiku Ewropew tal-EEA dwar l-Immaniġġjar tar-Riżorsi u l-Iskart (ETC/RWM) u b'kollaborazzjoni man-netwerk tal-pajjiżi tal-EEA (Eionet). L-Eurostat qed tiġbor dejta dwar l-iskart, u mill-2008 hija se tospita ċ-ċentri ta' dejta ambjentali dwar ir-riżorsi, il-prodotti u l-iskart.
